metadata.sermon_title: Twelfth Sunday After Pentecost / Trinity Sunday / Second Sunday After Pentecost
metadata.notes: The sermon combines a Trinitarian focus with a traditionalist emphasis on the theology of sin and the Book of Common Prayer.

freedom_from_critical_parent_CP.score_explanation: 10 = Completely free from coercive judgments. 0 = Very dominant Critical Parent.
freedom_from_critical_parent_CP.analysis: The preacher utilizes a 'Theological CP' to critique modern liturgical changes, insisting on the necessity of labeling the self as a 'miserable offender.' This creates a dogmatic requirement for self-abasement as a prerequisite for grace.
quotes: The removal of this line has robbed us of a powerful buttress...
The depth of which the psalmist is actually speaking here is the depth of the knowledge that he and everyone else is a 'miserable offender.'

healthy_care_NP.score_explanation: 10 = Healthy, non-smothering care. 0 = Absent or smothering.
healthy_care_NP.analysis: The Nurturing Parent is strong in the first half, using the analogy of a desperate parent to illustrate God's love. It is supportive but leans toward creating a 'Victim' status for the listener to be rescued.
quotes: You would make a complete fool of yourself if you thought it might get your child’s attention.
God’s love spends itself to the very last drop.

adult.analysis: There is scholarly Adult processing regarding the Greek context of Paul's letters and liturgical history. However, the Adult is often bypassed by emotional appeals to 'the depths' and 'catastrophe.'
quotes: The one that we read today is the longest, richest, and fullest of all his valedictory blessings.
Notice the surprising order of the words...

freedom_from_adapted_child_AC.score_explanation: 10 = Free from fear/compliance. 0 = Strong Adapted Child (fear culture).
freedom_from_adapted_child_AC.analysis: The sermon explicitly invites the listener into the Adapted Child position—specifically the 'Miserable Offender' role. It suggests that health is found only in admitting 'there is no health in us.'
quotes: Before God, none of us can hold up our heads.

free_child_FC.analysis: Joy is present but it is a 'permitted' joy that only occurs after the Adapted Child has sufficiently repented. It is not spontaneous but conditional.

transaction_analysis.analysis: The preacher speaks as a wise, slightly grieving Parent (Paul/God analogy) to a struggling, failing Child (Corinthians/Congregation).
transaction_analysis.ulterior_motives: Social: 'Let us study the Trinity.' Psychological: 'You are more broken than you realize, and you must accept this label to be loved.'
transaction_analysis.risk_explanation: The 'Bait and Switch' risk: The sermon starts with the 'unconditional love' of the Trinity but moves into a rigid requirement for the 'miserable offender' identity.

detected_games.name: Bait & Switch

formula_g_analysis.con: The promise of a God who loves 'without calculation' (Trinity section).
formula_g_analysis.gimmick: The listener's desire for unconditional acceptance.
formula_g_analysis.switch: The shift to the necessity of the 'miserable offender' label and the 'fear of the Lord.'
formula_g_analysis.payoff: The listener feels small and 'unhealthy' but 'saved'—maintaining dependency on the preacher's system.

evidence_quotes: God’s love... is not dependent on the worthiness of the other.
The removal of this line [there is no health in us] has robbed us...

detected_games.name: Ain't It Awful

formula_g_analysis.con: Lamenting the loss of traditional liturgy.
formula_g_analysis.gimmick: Nostalgia and shared frustration with 'modern' changes.
formula_g_analysis.switch: Moving from liturgical critique to universal human depravity.
formula_g_analysis.payoff: A shared sense of 'righteous' misery and superiority over 'shallow' modernists.

evidence_quotes: The removal of this line has robbed us of a powerful buttress...
It seems that there are many who do not want to hear that we are 'miserable offenders'...

preacher_roles.rescuer: High. The preacher offers the 'path of life' through a specific type of confession.
preacher_roles.persecutor: Low-Medium. Indirectly persecutes those who removed the 'miserable offender' line from the prayer book.

drama_triangle_analysis.congregation_position: Victim. The congregation is framed as 'self-destructive children' or 'miserable offenders' who cannot stand on their own.
drama_triangle_analysis.escape_possibilities: Limited. The 'escape' offered is further submission to the 'Parent' (God/Liturgy) rather than Adult autonomy.

conclusion_and_recommendation.summary: The sermon is a classic example of 'Parental' homiletics. While it offers a beautiful description of the Trinity as self-giving love, it psychologically undermines the listener by insisting on a 'no health in us' identity. It creates a double-bind: God's love is unconditional, yet one must adopt a 'miserable' self-image to truly access it. This reinforces dependency and the Adapted Child ego state, potentially leading to religious shame rather than authentic Free Child joy.
strengths: Strong use of metaphor (the desperate parent).
High emotional resonance and empathy in the first half.
areas_for_improvement: Over-reliance on the Critical Parent to enforce theological definitions of sin.
The 'Bait and Switch' between unconditional grace and the requirement of self-abasement.
conclusion_and_recommendation.advice_for_game_free_communication: Try addressing the congregation as 'Adults' who can choose goodness, rather than 'Children' who have no health in them. Shift from 'You must feel miserable to be saved' to 'As capable Adults, how do we respond to this great love?'
